    #######TASK 
    Provide a factually correct and detailed textual description of the game compiled from the information presented above from different sources, in more than 1000 words.
            "Cap:": represents the captions published in the online portal usually within 30 seconds of the event.
            "E:" represents events recorded exactly after the event happened.
    Don't mention sources of information like commentators or captions, write as if you saw them live.
summary:
The derby between Real Madrid and Atlético Madrid at the Santiago Bernabéu was a tale of two sides with contrasting forms and ambitions. Real Madrid, determined to impose their dominance, faced their city rivals Atlético Madrid, enduring a frustrating night as they sought to find a breakthrough. The contest unfurled with thrilling pace, tactical discipline, and individual brilliance as one side triumphed and the other faltered.

From the opening whistle, Atlético Madrid initiated the first half looking to assert themselves immediately. With the kick-off at 00:00 on the clock, Atlético Madrid looked to control possession but were quickly thwarted by early interruptions; at 00:14, the ball went out of play, a sign of the scrappy battle that would follow. Real Madrid quickly took control, winning the subsequent throw-in, which became a routine sight in the match as the ball frequently found its way out of play.

The physical nature of the encounter was clear from the outset, with Atlético committing an early foul at 00:58, giving Real Madrid their first indirect free-kick. This set a precedent for the visitors’ aggressive approach. Real Madrid reciprocated with shots both on and off-target, building pressure. By the third minute, Real Madrid had already attempted a shot at goal, albeit off target, showcasing their attacking intent.

More stoppages soon followed, with Real Madrid being granted another corner at 06:35. It was clear that Zinedine Zidane's men were exploiting set-pieces, putting Atlético’s backline under constant duress. In quick succession, a series of corners and shots on goal, most notably at 09:03, resulted in Real Madrid scoring their first goal of the match, putting them ahead. The timing and accuracy of their set-pieces were exemplary, leading to the early breakthrough.

Atlético sought a reprieve, attempting to regroup. However, Real Madrid’s defensive solidity coupled with their high pressing did not allow Atlético any ease of possession. Throw-ins became a frequent feature at both ends, illustrating the physicality and tactical caution of both teams. At 11:57, Atlético Madrid managed to win a throw-in but struggled to maintain meaningful possession, often resorting to long clearances.

The first real flash of creativity and attacking prowess came from Karim Benzema at 14:09, who put in a dangerous cross into the box, only for Atlético’s resolve to see the ball cleared. Real Madrid won another corner, constantly probing and forcing their rivals to defend deep. Further pressure from set pieces resulted in a spectacular save at 15:33 by the Atlético Madrid goalkeeper, denying Raphael Varane's powerful header from a crisis-inducing corner.

Noteworthy mentions must include the valiant exploits of Luka Modric and Isco, who orchestrated Real Madrid’s midfield, dictating play and frequently involving their teammates in intricate passing moves. By the 16th minute, Isco had tested Jan Oblak with a shot from the edge of the box, a routine save belying the potent threat carried by Real Madrid's midfielders.

The first half was also marred by physical confrontations. Tensions barely diffused as Atlético Madrid picked up the game's first yellow card at 25:29 after Koke's tackle was deemed reckless by the referee. Real Madrid’s free-kick opportunities continued to mount but only added to Atlético’s frustrations as they struggled to build any momentum themselves.

Even Atletico’s notable forwards like Kevin Gameiro were kept under wrap by a vigilant Real Madrid defense, backed by the immense shot-stopping abilities of Keylor Navas. Whenever Atletico pushed forward, they were met with formidable opposition, leading to very few attempts on Real Madrid's goal.

In another fascinating chapter of the first half, Daniel Carvajal of Real Madrid had to receive treatment after a knock, but it wasn’t until the beginning of the second half that he was substituted due to injury, introducing Nacho for defensive solidity. The half closed with Real Madrid clearly in control, boasting a one-goal lead and brimming with confidence.

As the second half commenced at 00:00, Real Madrid wasted no time in asserting their dominance. With Daniel Carvajal unable to continue, Nacho was brought on, adding fresh legs to the dynamics of the defense. The first few minutes maintained the high tempo with both teams eager to seize control. Nonetheless, Atlético’s Stefan Savic swiftly ran afoul of the referee, conceding a foul at 01:51, a testament to the continued aggressive stance of the visitors.

The first notable incident of the second half unfolded as Isco, vehement in his challenges, received a yellow card at 02:51, illustrating the tightrope Real Madrid walked between intensity and recklessness. This competitive edge, however, did not deter them from their attacking pursuits.

Cristiano Ronaldo, having so far orchestrated play from deeper positions, found himself constantly involved in dangerous areas. A spillover from their contemporaneous dominance, Real Madrid's chances kept coming, one such leading to a second goal at 27:42. Ronaldo, with brilliant foresight and technique, struck with precision, doubling Real Madrid's lead, much to the home crowd's jubilation.

Atletico Madrid’s reaction was immediate, injecting fresh energy with substitutions at 11:50 and 12:07 – Fernando Torres replacing Kevin Gameiro, and Nicolas Gaitan coming on for Saul. Nevertheless, Atletico’s frustration only deepened as they struggled to convert possession into meaningful chances. Koke’s effort at 14:25 epitomized their plight, his shot from distance sailing off-target, encapsulating their evening’s woes.

The final substitutions made by Zinedine Zidane at 22:00, swapping Isco for Marco Asensio and subsequently introducing Lucas for Karim Benzema at 31:57, ensured tactical flexibility and attacking depth were maintained, crucial in stabilizing and extending their advantage.

Tensions threatened to spill over with several fouls by both sides, but Real Madrid managed to hold their composure. A notable incident involved Stefan Savic at 37:20 receiving a yellow card due to persistent fouling, signaling a broader theme of Atletico’s unraveling discipline.

The critical juncture of the match arrived at 40:06 when Real Madrid sealed their victory with a third goal. Demonstrating clinical finishing, Cristiano Ronaldo completed his hat-trick with a close-range effort following a deft layoff by substitute Lucas. This goal cemented their superiority and encapsulated Ronaldo's exceptional influence on the match.

As the game winded down, Atletico Madrid mustered late surges, yet Real Madrid’s resolute defense led by Sergio Ramos and Raphael Varane held firm. Luka Modric’s near-miss at 42:53 was among the many moments defining Real Madrid’s attacking intent and creativity throughout the game. Even the final whistles of fouls and indirect free-kicks towards the end of the game were mere formalities, with the outcome already decided.

By full-time at 48:18, Real Madrid had comprehensively dispatched their city rivals with a 3-0 victory. The result was a testament to their tactical acumen, individual brilliance, and collective resolve. Zinedine Zidane’s men demonstrated why they are considered one of Europe’s elite teams, showcasing not just skill but a hunger and determination that augur well for their future endeavors. For Atlético Madrid, the night was one of missed opportunities and reflective lessons as they left the field, recognizing the chasm they must bridge to regain parity with their illustrious rivals.
